cards.front: What are Newton's laws of motion?
cards.back:
1. An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.
2. The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.
3. For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.stem: Which of the following is NOT one of Newton's laws of motion?
options: An apple falls from a tree due to gravity (First Law)
A moving object will stay in motion unless acted upon by an external force (Second Law)
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction (Third Law)
The mass of an object does not affect its acceleration (Neglected Law)
questions.rationale: The neglected law is a misconception, as the mass of an object plays a significant role in determining its acceleration.

insights.title: Newton's Laws of Motion Insight
insights.takeaway: Newton's first law (law of inertia) states that an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion, unless acted upon by an external force; his second law relates the acceleration of an object to its mass and the net force acting upon it, while the third law explains that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction

cards.front: What is Newton's first law of motion?
cards.back: Newton's First Law, also known as the Law of Inertia, states that an object at rest will stay at rest and an object in motion will stay in motion with a constant velocity unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

cards.front: What is Newton's second law of motion?
cards.back: Newton's Second Law, also known as F = ma, states that the acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.

cards.front: What is Newton's third law of motion?
cards.back: Newton's Third Law, also known as the Action-Reaction Principle, states that for every action (force) in a closed system, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.stem: What is the second law of motion, also known as Newton's Law of Acceleration, stated as?
options: A) F = ma
B) F = mv²
C) F = ma²
D) F = mv
questions.rationale: The second law of motion is stated as F = ma, where F is the net force acting on an object, m is its mass and a is its acceleration.

questions.stem: Which of the following is NOT one of Newton's laws of motion?
options: A) Inertia
B) Action and Reaction
C) Law of Acceleration
D) Law of Friction
questions.rationale: Law of Friction is not one of Newton's laws of motion.

questions.stem: How does the third law of motion relate to the action and reaction forces?
options: A) Action and reaction forces always act in opposite directions
B) Action and reaction forces have equal magnitudes but opposite directions
C) Action and reaction forces are always parallel
D) Action and reaction forces are always perpendicular
questions.rationale: Action and reaction forces have equal magnitudes but opposite directions.

insights.title: Newton's Laws of Motion - First Law
insights.takeaway: An object at rest tends to stay at rest, and an object in motion tends to stay in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by a net force.

insights.title: Newton's Laws of Motion - Second Law
insights.takeaway: The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the applied force and inversely proportional to its mass (F = ma).

insights.title: Newton's Laws of Motion - Third Law
insights.takeaway: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

cards.front: What are Newton's three laws of motion?
cards.back:
1. An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by a net force.
2. The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.
3. For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.stem: What is the sum of the first and second Newton's laws of motion?
options: The total momentum remains constant
The total force acting on an object equals its mass times acceleration
The total kinetic energy remains constant
An object in motion will stay in motion unless acted upon by an external force
questions.rationale: The first law (inertia) states that an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by an external force. The second law (F=ma) relates the net force acting on an object to its acceleration.

insights.title: Newton's Laws of Motion Insight
insights.takeaway: Newton's First Law, also known as the Law of Inertia, states that an object at rest will stay at rest and an object in motion will continue in its state of motion unless acted upon by an external force. Newton's Second Law, or F=ma, explains how the acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass. Finally, Newton's Third Law asserts that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
